Award.AwardTitle: Transient Intermediates in Proton and Electron Transfer
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamic & Mechanism B Program of the Chemistry Division, Professor Frantisek Turecek of the Department of Chemistry at University of Washington, Seattle, will develop new methods for improved protein sequencing by mass spectrometry. The goal of this research is first to gain deep understanding of peptide backbone dissociations that provide information on the peptide amino acid sequence which is then spliced to complete the sequence of the parent protein. Protein sequencing is the critical step in determining mutations, post-translational modifications, and damage that cause many diseases and degenerative processes. Cancer, Parkinson and Alzheimer diseases and aging all include protein changes as one of the major causes disrupting cellular processes and their regulation. This research group is also well-positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students of different cultural backgrounds including those underrepresented in physical and life sciences.

Mass spectrometry is the method of choice for protein and peptide analysis. In the so-called bottom-up approach, the protein or a mixture thereof is enzymatically cleaved to a mixture of peptides that are separated on-line and analyzed. Mass spectrometry analysis provides valuable information on the peptide mass and amino acid sequence and composition. The information can be evaluated by matching against a data base to find the generic protein for which there is a known gene. However, proteins from organisms lacking genome data, or modified proteins due to disease or damage must be analyzed by the so-called de novo sequencing, implying complete sequence readout from the mass spectrometry data alone. In this project, new methods are investigated and developed to improve de novo protein sequencing. The project has several goals: (1) A new method of peptide capture and chemical modification on solid phase support is being developed to simplify peptide mixtures and increase the level of sequence readout. (2) Fundamental studies of peptide ion dissociations following electron transfer will be carried out to determine the effects of ion 3D structure and energy deposition. (3) A new UV photodissociation method is introduced to provide a different means of activation, causing efficient dissociation of gas-phase peptide ions. Results from these studies will be used to refine the current theoretical model of peptide ion activation and dissociation and utilize it for prediction of ion behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Chemical reactions often do not proceed in a single step but involve unstable transient intermediates that are formed in the course of the reaction sequence but disappear as the reaction is completed.  Some important reactions involving biomolecules, such as DNA radiation damage and protein degradation by reactive radicals, are known or presumed to involve such transient intermediates. However, generating such intermediates and determining their structure is quite challenging, presenting a considerable intellectual merit.

To study these highly reactive species, we tag them with a positive charge and trap the positive ions in an electromagnetic ion trap.  The conditions in the trap are favorable for extending the ion lifetime, so they can be studied and their structure be elucidated. This NSF funded project deals with laser spectroscopy of transient cation radicals derived from peptides and oligonucleotides which are components of proteins and DNA, respectively.  We have constructed equipment and designed experiments that have allowed us to obtain action spectra at wavelengths covering the ultraviolet and visible regions of the spectrum.  We discovered that response to light in this region is highly characteristic of the nature and structure of transient cation radicals.  To interpret the spectra, we have applied computational methods using quantum theory that allowed us to determine both ion structures and their electronic properties.  The computations at the scale applied in this project have been made possible by a supercomputer cluster funded by the NSF. Agreement between the experimental and computed spectra were used to discover and assign new features in DNA ionization damage, namely novel and unexpected forms of the nucleobase thymine, and electron distribution in ionized DNA. These new finding potentially have broad impact on our understanding of DNA.  Another broad impact part of this project concerns laser photodissociation to study loose (non-covalent) interactions of peptides. Our approach relies on  creating an extremely short-lived reactive intermediate, a carbene,  that can reactively bind to the peptide or protein counterpart in the complex and thus tag the contact site (see the image). These studies were performed on the same equipment as the DNA-related research and allowed us to understand the binding of a small peptide that had previously been shown to alleviate brain trauma in mice.  The general broad impact of these studies is in modeling non-covalent interactions between protein motifs with the goal of gaining a fundamental understanding of the interactions that govern binding to proteins.        


Last Modified: 09/19/2018
Modified by: Frantisek Turecek

However, generating such intermediates and determining their structure is quite challenging, presenting a considerable intellectual merit. To study these highly reactive species, we tag them with a positive charge and trap the positive ions in an electromagnetic ion trap. The conditions in the trap are favorable for extending the ion lifetime, so they can be studied and their structure be elucidated. This NSF funded project deals with laser spectroscopy of transient cation radicals derived from peptides and oligonucleotides which are components of proteins and DNA, respectively. We have constructed equipment and designed experiments that have allowed us to obtain action spectra at wavelengths covering the ultraviolet and visible regions of the spectrum. We discovered that response to light in this region is highly characteristic of the nature and structure of transient cation radicals. To interpret the spectra, we have applied computational methods using quantum theory that allowed us to determine both ion structures and their electronic properties. The computations at the scale applied in this project have been made possible by a supercomputer cluster funded by the NSF. Agreement between the experimental and computed spectra were used to discover and assign new features in DNA ionization damage, namely novel and unexpected forms of the nucleobase thymine, and electron distribution in ionized DNA. These new finding potentially have broad impact on our understanding of DNA. Another broad impact part of this project concerns laser photodissociation to study loose (non-covalent) interactions of peptides. These studies were performed on the same equipment as the DNA-related research and allowed us to understand the binding of a small peptide that had previously been shown to alleviate brain trauma in mice. The general broad impact of these studies is in modeling non-covalent interactions between protein motifs with the goal of gaining a fundamental understanding of the interactions that govern binding to proteins.
